slidelink.displaytext: Unit 1 : Equipment types and application areas
Unit 2: Earthmoving equipment and production levels: dump trucks and bulldozers
Unit 3: Earthmoving equipment and production levels: excavators and graders

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
In Unit 1:

- You will be able to identify different types of equipment used on earthmoving operations

- You will be able to differentiate the use cases for each type of earthmoving operation

In Unit 2:

- You will be able to explain different types and capacities of dump trucks

- You will be able to calculate production levels for bulldozers in different site conditions using equipment charts

In Unit 3:

- You will be able to calculate production levels for excavators in different site conditions

- You will be able to explain application areas and production levels for graders

Basics of Equipment Selection

Selection of a an appropriate piece of equipment directly affects productivity, profit, as well as safety of the heavy civil projects.

You might ask whether this excavator Can load this large dump truck?!!!

The key issue is that the selected equipment must match the job type and size, and site conditions.

Identify Suitable Equipment

First step in selection of equipment is to identify suitable machines the can carry out the job.

Some equipment are designed to carry out a certain task.

For example, rollers are mainly used for compaction.

Whereas some machines can carry out a variety of operations.

For instance, bulldozers can excavate, spread earth material, rip the rocks, backfill, and some other operation. These equipment, however, might need changing the end-effector to do certain tasks.

Earthwork Operations and Equipment Packages

This table includes main earthwork operations and equipment packages.

Identify Physical Properties

In addition to the type of the job, it is important to determine type and physical properties of the earth material and choose the right power, end-effector, and accessories for the equipment.

Heavy crawler track equipment => used for excavation and loading of rock material and hard surfaces.

Rubber-tired and medium/light crawler track equipment => used for excavation and loading of medium and loose material.

Equipment Selection

The next important factor in selection of equipment is to analyze whether the size and capacity of the equipment matches the volume of work.

Overloading a machine can damage it in two ways:

• Structural or mechanical damage

• Stability failure

Maintenance and Support

Another important factor is to assess the availability of on-time and proper maintenance and technical support for the considered equipment.

Job conditions are harsh in heavy civil project and the rates of various mechanical failures are high, and the equipment require frequent maintenance. So it is essential to make sure that the maintenance and repair services are available for the selected equipment.

Equipment Selection Considerations

The following factors should be considered during equipment selection process:

1. Tires and tracks

2. Buckets and blades

3. End-effectors and accessories

1. Tires and tracks

As mentioned before, crawler track and rubber tires have different coefficients of traction in different surfaces.

So it is better to select a system that has a better traction in the work zone.

1. Tires and tracks (Con't)

Moreover, track and tires have different affects rolling resistances in various surface types.

As a result, selection of a track or wheeled equipment can affect required effort, travel times, productivity, as well as the wear and tear of the equipment.

1. Tires and tracks (Con't)

This table provides a set of recommendations based on job requirements.

2. Buckets and blades

The shape and size of the buckets and their teeth depend on the type of the material to be moved or excavated.

Wider buckets are typically used for excavation and loading of soft and loose material (the bucket in right side), whereas narrow and longer buckets are used for digging in hard surfaces (left side bucket).

2. Buckets and blades

Different teeth options are available for the buckets:

Narrow, sharp, and long teeth are used for penetration in hard surfaces.

Short and wide teeth are used for most regular operation.

This figure shows standard short and long teeth together with a specially designed bucket tooth for penetration in hard surfaces.

2. Buckets and blades (con’t)

Bucket used for loading loose material or used for trimming and sloping are toothless.

2. Buckets and blades

Different blade forms are also used for bulldozers.

Straight blades are the most common form of blades for bulldozers which are mainly used for stripping, surface excavation, and short distance push.

Angle blades are mainly used for ditch excavation and side casting. Angle blades are typically wider than straight blades and also could be used for excavation in soft and fine material surfaces.

2. Buckets and blades

Different blade forms are also used for bulldozers.

Cushion blade are primarily used for pushing scrapers during loading as they are reinforced for this task.

These blades can also be used for light excavations.

Universal blades have tilted sides which reduce spillage of the materials from the sides, which make these blades ideal for long pushes of earth material.

3. End-effectors and accessories

Some equipment types can carry out different operations if equipped with proper end-effectors / accessories.

There are variety of end-effectors /accessories for excavators, such as hammers to break rocks and concrete (as shown in the image), roadheader to grind hard surfaces, and cutters to cut asphalt and concrete.

3. End-effectors and accessories

A set of small rippers could be installed on graders for light ripping.

Bulldozer rippers are larger and used for heavy ripping in hard surfaces.

Quiz:

Which one of the following factors is not as important as the others in selection of equipment?

a. Size of the equipment

b. Type of the equipment

c. Model of the equipment

d. Crawler track or tire

Quiz 2:

Drag and drop these blade figures in the correct answer boxes.

Universal blades are used for pushing material in long distances, angle blades are employed for finishing slopes and cutting ditches, and straight blades are used for common operations, including backfilling.

Universal blades are used for pushing material in long distances, angle blades are employed for finishing slopes and cutting ditches, and straight blades are used for common operations, including backfilling.
Choose the correct answer for each requirement.

Summary of Unit 1

1. It is critical to select an equipment fleet that matches the type and size of the required work

2. Crawler track and rubber tires have different performances in different jobsite conditions

3. Suitable bucket and blade shapes should be selected for different site conditions

4. There are various types of end-effectors and accessories for some equipment, such as excavators and bulldozers, which can diversify their application areas

Dump Trucks

Trucks are the most common type of hauling equipment with rather low cost, because they can travel with high speed.

Dump trucks can be classified in different ways:

· On-highway and off-highway dump trucks, some classes of dump trucks can not operate on public roads and they are only allowed to work within construction or mining sites, because of their wide bodies and very heavy weights.

· Rigid and articulated-body dump trucks.

· Dump trucks can also be classified based on the way that they dump their load. Although most dump trucks are rear-dump, but there are some special-purpose trucks which are designed to dump their load from the side or bottom of their bed.

Dump Truck Capacity

Trucks are the most common type of hauling equipment with rather low cost, because they can travel with high speed.

Dump trucks can be classified in different ways:

· On-highway and off-highway dump trucks, some classes of dump trucks can not operate on public roads and they are only allowed to work within construction or mining sites, because of their wide bodies and very heavy weights

· Rigid and articulated-body dump trucks

· Dump trucks can also be classified based on the way that they dump their load. Although most dump trucks are rear-dump, but there are some special-purpose trucks which are designed to dump their load from the side or bottom of their bed

Dump Truck Tarps

In addition, a tarping system is commonly used to cover the open-box bed of dump trucks in public roads.

On-highway Dump trucks

As discussed before, dump trucks can be classified into on-highway and off-highway dump trucks.

· This type of dump trucks are designed to meet the size and weight limitation of public roads, so they could be used to haul earth material (and other construction material such as hot asphalt) using public roads.

· They are usually rigid-frame and rear-dump.

There are different sizes and capacities for on-highway dump trucks.

Off-highway Dump trucks

· These type of dump trucks are used in both mining and heavy civil projects

· There are various types of off-highway dump trucks with various capacities. They are chosen based on the technical requirement and road specifications of the jobsite.

1. Rigid body

· Usually have high capacities (could be more than 267 m3 or 350 yd3)

· The roads should be wide enough without tight turns

Off-highway dump trucks are wide and very heavy and are not allowed to operate on public roads. They are usually transported by truck trailers as oversize load in highways.

Off-highway Dump trucks

2. Articulated body (articulated hauler)

· Limited capacity (less than 25 m3)

· Mostly all-wheel drive

· Flexible and can operate in low quality and narrow roads and high slopes (rough terrain) with tight turns

Quiz:

Tarp system in on-highway dump truck is used to:

a. Increase capacity of dump trucks

b. Increase safety in public roads

c. Increase speed of dump trucks

d. Reduce fuel consumption of dump trucks

Bulldozers

Bulldozer, also called dozer, is a tractor-power equipment with a blade attached in front

There are two types of dozers:

• Crawler type dozers

• Rubber tire type dozers

The majority of the dozers, however, are crawler type as the provide much better traction and usable power in rough terrains.

Bulldozers

Bulldozers are used for various purposes, but the most common applications are:

• Stripping and land clearing

• Sidehill cuts

• Ditching

• Backfilling

• Ripping rocks or frozen ground

• Spreading

• Slot dozing

• Blade-to-blade dozing

Blade to blade, or side by side dozing, is a special configuration of dozers to push the material beside each other to minimize the spillage of the loose material from the one side (or both sides) of the blade

Bulldozer Capacity and Productivity

A bulldozers does not have a certain volumetric capacity, and it depends on:

• The material in front of the blade

• Type of the material it operates on

For example, some cohesive material such as clay boil and heap in front of the blade.

Productivity of the dozers is typically greater in coesionless material, such as sand and gravel.

Bulldozer Capacity and Productivity

Bulldozer cycles can be divided into push, return, and maneuver tasks:

Thus, the productivity can be calculated as.

All times are in minute

Bulldozer Capacity and Productivity: Example

A dozer pushes an average blade load of 4.8 cubic meters. The average push distance is 30 meters. Calculate the production in loose cubic meters. Material is loose sand.

Bulldozer Production Curves

Most equipment manufacturing companies provide production curves for their dozers, based on “ideal conditions”.

This figure shows sample production curves for two types of dozers with straight blades. For example, if we want to use a 220 horsepower dozer in a stripping operation with an average pushing distance of 90 meters.

The average production rate will be 150 cubic meters per hour.

Correction Factors

Since these curves provide the production rates under “ideal conditions”, correction factors should be applied

Sample correction factors:

Operator skill

Highly skilled: 1; average skill: 0.75; low-level: 0.6

Efficiency

Or active minutes per hour, e.g. 45 min/hr => correction factor is 0.75

Material type:

Very loose: 1.2; hard and frozen: 0.8; very cohesive: 0.8; rock and blasted: 0.6-0.8

Low visibility

Fog, low light, or very dusty: 0.8

Group work

Blade-to-blade dozing: 1.2 (because it minimizes the material spillage from the sides)

Quiz 2:

Using this performance chart, what is the expected production of a 220hp dozer in 30 meter push with an efficiency of 55 min/hr.

a. 323 cubic meters/hr

b. 355 cubic meters/hr

c. 372 cubic meters/hr

d. 420 cubic meters/hr

Quiz 3:

A bulldozer will have the highest production rate in excavation of :

a. Cohesive clay

b. Hard and frozen grounds

c. Blasted rocks

d. Loose sand and gravel

Summary of Unit 2

1. Different types of dump trucks, including on-highway and off-highway, and rigid and articulated body dump trucks were discussed

2. Characteristics and production levels for bulldozers in different site conditions were explained

3. Application of production curves for bulldozers were demonstrated

Excavators

Excavators are among the most versatile construction equipment and used for variety of purposes.

Similar to bulldozers, there are two main types of excavators:

• Crawler type

• Wheeled type

The crawler excavators are the most common type as they provide much better traction and are more stable in rough terrains.

Excavator Arm

Main components of an excavator arm are: Stick cylinder, Boom, Dipper stick, bucket cylinder, bucket.

Excavator Bucket Capacity

A main factor in excavator production is the bucket capacity.

For example in this image, the material volume is almost the same as the physical volume of the bucket, which is called struck capacity.

But in this case, the material volume is greater than the physical volume of the bucket, which is called heaped capacity.

Productivity

Excavator production rate can be calculated with the following formula. This equation can estimate the volume of a excavated material in an hour, which depends on jobsite conditions

Where:

Q = heaped bucket capacity

F = bucket fill factor

AS:D = angle of swing and depth of cut correction

t = cycle time in seconds

E = efficiency (min per hour)

Volume correction for loose volume to bank volume = 1/ (1+swell factor)

This table presents the fill factor for different types of material.

As presented here, large rocks and boulders are the most difficult items to fill the bucket, which result in lower productivity.

Cycle Times

Typical cycle times for average size excavators are (usually provided by manufacturer):

However, these times can vary depending on some factors such as:

Operator skill, material type, angle of swing, positioning of the equipment, and visibility.

Digging Envelope

Excavator manufacturers provide a detailed graph which shows the range dimensions of their products.

A critical parameter is the maximum digging depth.

The best productivity could be achieved in the range of 30%-50% of the maximum depth.

Correction Factor (AS:D)

How to find the correction factor (AS:D) for angle of swing and excavation depth?

This table provides correction factors for the effects of angle of swing and depth of excavation.

As you can see here, a pattern is noticeable.

As the angle of swing increases, the factor drops. The reason is that the excavator needs to swing for longer time, which reduces overall production.

The trend for the depth, however, is different. As you can see here, the best performance can be achieved at the optimum digging depth, which is around 30%-50% of the maximum depth. Deeper or shallower excavations will result in lower productivity.

And the benchmark is the optimum depth with the swing angle of 90 degrees.

Productivity Example

Given the following information, find the estimated production in bank cubic meters

• Size of bucket: 2.7 cubic meter

• Material: Sand and gravel

• Maximum digging depth: 7.7 m

• Actual depth of excavation: 2.5 m

• Angle of swing: 120°

• Swell percent for this material: 15%

• Active minutes per hour: 50 minutes

Productivity Solution 1

Step 1: Size of bucket is given = 2.7 cubic meter

Step 2: Bucket fill factor for sand and gravel using the table described before

We can use a number in middle, let’s say 103%.

Productivity Solution 2

Step 3: Cycle times using the provided table.

Using the average times, the total cycle times will be 19 seconds

Optimum depth: 40% of 7.7m = 3.08 m

Excavation depth/optimum depth = 2.5/3.08 ~ %80

Given the table introduced before:

With Percentage of the optimum depth of 80% and swing angle of 120 degrees, the AS:D factor is 0.86

Productivity Solution 3

Step 4: Efficiency factor is 50/60

Step 5: Swell percentage is 15%

Step 6: Overall productivity:

Quiz:

Choose the configurations that has the lowest production.

Graders

Graders are multipurpose equipment employed for shaping, grading, bank sloping, ditching, spreading, mixing, and light stripping purposes.

Graders blades are commonly called moldboard that are mainly used for shaping and leveling.

Graders blades are attached to a circular mechanism which enables them to rotate easily. This mechanism is called circle.

Small rippers can be installed in the rear end of graders. These rippers are only used for light ripping of soil grounds.

Grader Operations

Grader are used for a variety of operations, including:

• Leveling surfaces

• Ditch cuts

• Creating a bank slope

• Cleaning ditches

• Moving windrows

• Haul-road maintenance

• Spreading

• Mixing

Time Estimation

Usually time estimation is used to assess the productivity of graders:

The parameters in this formula are:

P = number of passes required

D = distance traveled in each pass

S = speed of the grader

E = grader efficiency factor (usually 60%-70%)

Grader Time Example

Leveling of a 300 meter embankment requires two levelling passes in first gear (3.7 km/h) and two shaping passes in second gear (6 km/hr).

Quiz 2:

Maintenance of a 800 meter haul road requires two levelling passes in first gear (3.5 km/h) and a shaping pass in second gear (5.5 km/hr). Grader efficiency is 63%. The required time is:

a. 45 minutes

b. 48 minutes

c. 53 minutes

d. 57 minutes

Quiz 2 Solution:

Total Time = d. 57 Minutes

Summary of Unit 3

1. It is essential to study equipment manufacturers’ handbook to determine equipment capacities and physical limitations

2. Characteristics and production levels for excavators and graders in different site conditions were explained

Summary of Module 4

1. Candidate equipment for a certain task should match the type and size of the operation

2. Main equipment selection considerations, including tires and tracks, buckets and blades, and end-effectors and accessories, were explained

3. We discussed how to assess the performance of bulldozers, excavators, and graders using equipment charts, correction factors, and theoretical formulas
